review_title: Nice work environment with almost no negative experience.
job_title: Lab Helper in New York, NY
pros: Engaging and comfortable work environment.
cons: The experience of your time at Rockefeller depends entirely on which lab you get placed at (if you are going for a lab-related job). Generally, most labs are fine to work at as the people are very understanding and decent but as is the case with everything else, there are always a few who are not. However, this isn't necessarily an inherent con for the university itself. I personally have not had any serious negative experiences here.

job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in New York, NY
pros: Rockefeller is a fantastic university with great benefits and one of the best academic cultures I've ever experienced.
cons: There are issues with every academic job (particularly with low pay) and each experience will be heavily dependent upon which lab you join.

review_title: great place to work, little room for advancement

job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY

review_title: It is what you make of it
job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY

review_title: Great place, depending on the lab

job_title: Teacher in New York, NY
pros:
The University has a great medical insurance plan, with he choice of two options: The Rockefeller University Choice Plan or The Rockefeller University Managed Care Plan.

The University has great center that provides developmentally appropriate early childhood education for the youngest members of the Rockefeller community, beginning at age 3 months. The teachers at the center patient, caring, and personable.

As a full-time employee, if you're attending school in your field of study, the University will reimburse 85% of the total tuition charges, registration, books, and necessary supplies.
cons:
As a teacher at the center you will not get the support needed from administration.

As a teacher at the center you'll start to feel undervalued but what teacher doesn't feel undervalued.

The philosophy and culture has changed. As a result, if you have an opinion or thoughts on how things can change it will be ignored.

job_title: Graduate Fellow in New York, NY
pros: Tons of flexibility in terms of what your personally pursue as a student
cons: Limited number of labs, little to no computational biologists

job_title: Research Associate in New York, NY

review_title: A great place to do science
job_title: Research Scientist in New York, NY

job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits and work environment
cons: Poor work-life balance, long hours.

job_title: Human Resources Administrator in New York, NY
pros: great community, academic excellence, supportive coworkers
cons: None that I can think of

job_title: Graduate Fellow in New York, NY
pros: There are many great benefits
cons: It can be a little insular

job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Rockefeller has an amazing sense of community at every level of the university's operations:  the mail clerks are old friends with the Nobel Laureates, the techs hang out with the post-docs and younger PIs. The relatively small campus reinforces  this friendliness, along with the wonderful faculty club and excellent public lectures and concerts, which take place every week. Everything at Rockefeller, from the ground-breaking science to even the most minor event is done with an incredible level of quality and care that surpasses any other university that I have spent time at for scientific meetings including Ivy League institutions. The high ratio of professors and research scientists to their apprentice  technicians, grad students and post-docs provides an incredible environment for intellectual growth and professional development. The benefits and compensation for regular employees as well as graduate students are significantly better than any of the larger NYC universities. The the small nurses office for employee walk-in appointments was more pleasant and professional and medically knowledgeable than 9/10 doctors I've ever visited in NYC.
cons: The location is not great for commuters.

review_title: Great place to be a grad student
job_title: Grad Student in New York, NY
pros: Good salary for a grad student. Everyone here is on a fellowship, so you're guaranteed funding for 5 years. There are good benefits. We have decent health and dental insurance. We also have insanely subsidized housing. Manhattan rent for less than $800 per month. There are even some good perks. The university provides computers and discretionary research spending money for all students. The Dean's office really cares about the students and do their best to help us. There is also a minimum of administrative red tape and departmental requirements: no quals, not too many required classes.
cons: Each lab has a unique culture. There are some in which the PI can be very demanding and on top of the grad students and some in which you will barely see them at all. Joining a bad lab can really affect your experience.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros: There's food at a lot of the meetings. Surrounded by very intelligent scientists. That's just about it; everything else sucks.
cons: Where do I begin? Extremely poor management. Micromanaged from people outside of my own department. Spent almost half a year with no supervisor so I was stuck doing busy work like cleaning closets. No training; was sent to my office on the first day with absolutely no training so I only learned things as they came up. Low pay. Cattiness. Favoritism. Got fired because my "performance was lacking" however my last performance evaluation was perfect and there was no verbal or written warnings between that evaluation and the termination. The real reason is because they play favorites and there is a lot of sucking up. Was asked for a reason or example of where my performance was lacking and was told that  they don't have to give me a reason. Lots of cliques like high school teenagers. Lazy coworkers. Lots and lots of system flaws and disconnect within their internal internet programs which makes communication between departments extremely challenging. I could go on for days about how miserable of an environment Rockefeller University is.

review_title: Hard to go anywhere if not a scientist
job_title: Rockefeller Press in New York, NY
pros: Really incredible institution (one of best in the world for bioscience)--smart people on every level and all areas, not just in the labs. Fantastic benefits and laid-back friendly atmosphere. Some people stay forever they like it so much. Also great place to start for young people with editorial and science backgrounds. Management can be very loyal to some--allowing telecommuting or other flexibility.
cons: Low, non-profit pay. Not high to begin with and increases come only with the rare promotion. Very hard to advance in general, especially if a non-scientist. Many people, including the PhDs, end up going to work in for-profit-pharma advertising because of pay. Management can be a little chaotic and immature at times, with turnover due to personality differences, though this may have changed with an overhaul.

review_title: good overall.  HOL needs assistance to learn management skills
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: HR is phenomenal; they look after employees very well.  The system is set up so that the whole university protects employees. Superb benefit and amazing campus and facilities.
cons: Salary (depending on one's position) is, as an academic/non-profit institution, not enough to support NYC living expenses. Promotion is non-existent if one's a lab staff (scientific).  Research assistants appear to be treated as "temporary" employees as the majority of them are new college graduates who will go to med or grad school in 1-2 years. For a more experienced lab technician, a research assistant position is not recommended at all.

review_title: Being a PhD student at Rockefeller has been wonderful
job_title: Graduate Student in New York, NY
pros:
Phenomenal labs investigating great areas of biomedical research
Flexibility of the graduate program (able to take courses at any school in NYC)
Able to work for any lab, or two at once
Each lab acts autonomously; so there is very little red tape, and it is incredibly easy to collaborate
PhD funded by Graduate Program for 5 years
Strong stipend with affordable housing on NY's Upper East Side
Incredible support for students with children
cons:
Each lab acts autonomously; so your Principal Investigator (PI) has incredible influence on your experience (make sure you carefully choose your PI)
Given the former, two PhD students with the same intellect and work ethic can have different experiences (which is partially the nature of science)

job_title: IT Staff in New York, NY
pros: Laid back atmosphere, co-workers for the most part, on campus cafeteria
cons: Pay. 401 lock down, no structure.  Lacking in progress.  No motivation, old boys school mentality, rarely pay for any type of training or seminars that would enhance performance or job skill.  Its like stepping back into time with HR and how to handle issues.  No training for anyone that is promoted to management with no prior skills of managing people.  Runs in spite of itself.

review_title: Great benefits (if you work for the right department), but basically an old boys' club
job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
Lots of vacation time (if your manager permits you to take it)
Good benefits
Pretty but somewhat remote campus
Can be a nice environment depending on your department
cons:
Low pay. 
No cooperation between departments.
Lots of crazy people who have worked there for 20 or 30 years and are completely inflexible
No centralization which causes confusion, waste, inefficiency

review_title: Do great work in a supportive environment
job_title: Copy Editor in New York, NY
pros: I worked at Rockefeller University Press (part of the university but pretty independent of it). I feel so lucky to have been a part of the press: the work was steady and challenging, the benefits are amazing (one of the best benefits packages anywhere), and my coworkers and the general atmosphere are very supportive and laid back. I feel like I learned a lot while I was here, and that my contributions were valued.
cons: PhD-level scientific subject material can be challenging until you get used to it. Because it's a small press, there are limited opportunities for advancement, but you'll feel very secure in whatever position you have.

review_title: An absolutely fabulous institution to work for and be a part of
job_title: Information Technology in New York, NY
pros: Rockefeller is truly a special place.  Many people have stayed at this university for many, many years.  Some stay even till retirement, which is a rarity these days.  There is an environment that breeds intellectual curiosity and inquiry at all levels of the environment.
cons: Perhaps the only bone to pick is that things move at a slower pace, but this is true of many places in academia.  Also, you have to be careful when it comes to starting new research or projects that the endeavor is something which truly benefits the human medical condition.  But this is more of a pro than anything

review_title: Nice place for benefits, but absolute no room for advancement. You start and end with the same title.
job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Beautiful campus.  Overall friendly atmosphere.  Relaxed environment.  Child friendly work community.  Fairly flexible about working hours. Nice place to be if you want to do research or be surrounded by esteemed science pioneers.
cons: Absolute no career advancement.  No pay scale or salary grades.  Salary is not commensurate with experience.  Yearly raises are minimal as they don't even do employee review. Hard for promotion opportunities within the science community.  You essentially start with a title, and leave with the same one.  Salary is not competitive to surrounding community.

review_title: Very comfortable University to work at in the city
job_title: Computer Support Specialist in Jersey City, NJ
pros: Beautiful campus to work out and you feel you are not in the city. No pressure job and many amazing benefits. Room for advancement if you put in the work and drive. Many employees have been there 10+ years. Free 24 hour gym on campus which is very nice and convenient. IT department is very laid back and very friendly people always willing to help and show you if you ask questions.
cons: Sometimes if a place is too comfortable you never want to leave and advance. But if you love your position why not stay there and prosper. Depends on the person and what they want out of life.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: location in tri-institute area, subsidized housing that is conveniently adjacent to campus, good child day care facility which at one time is very affordable.
cons: The particular lab environment is not good, constant high pressure, very little advice and guidance from the PI. The PI relies on his old fame and experience but loses his vision  to guide his group to achieve further success.

review_title: Great, if not the best, environment to work in but overall salary for an RA position low
job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: The Rockefeller Univ. is an amazing place to work at.  There are, as many people know, a number of excellent scientists here.  Core facilities and their availabilities are nothing compared to any other academic institutions I have ever worked at.  The campus is very small, and everyone works "together."  If you want something, you'll get it, whether that be on campus or outside the campus (cornell, columbia, Mt. Sinai, NYU to name a few that collaborate with many at RU).  The HR is on top of everything.  Again, it's a small place; things are well taken care of (this include the landscape, too!).  Oh, the benefits are second to none.  20days of vacation time?? I have never heard of it.  Are we in Europe??  Actually, it's VERY diverse, too.  Most likely, a lab consists of less than 50% Americans and the rest from all over the world.
cons:
The only cons: 
1. The salary is not realistic (for RA) for living in and around NYC.  One would typically get 3%-3.5% raise annually, which is NOT even enough to cover annually rising rent.  Starting salary for undergrad is 38000, masters 40000.  It's still better than (i hear) other academic institutions, but it's hard to get by without spending your saving (if one has ANY) or relying on one's parents (again, if you have any).  
2. Depending on which lab, I think, but RAs are pretty much treated as "technicians."  NOT research assistants.  Most postdocs whom we work with would only expect you to do bench tasks.  You would probably have to really demand you want to participate more.  In such a case, you'd be working much longer hours than full time in order to attain more intellectual independence.  BUT you would never get paid more.  the max salary for RAs is 50000 or so.

job_title: Research Associate in New York, NY
pros: Great freedom for the self-motivated to excel and collaborate with one another; light administrative burden, no departments.
cons: Like most universities, RU functions as a collection of eighty quasi-independent fiefdoms. Management styles among faculty run the gamut, so your experience is less dictated by RU culture and more by individual lab culture. Mentoring can be extensive or almost nonexistent. Benefits are excellent but pay is barely adequate given its Manhattan location, though typical of other NY universities and nonprofits. Opportunities for advancement can be limited given its size. Usually the only way up is out.

job_title: Administrative Assistant/Office Manager in New York, NY
pros: Best benefits I've ever had. Decent pay. Very nice people who care about what they do. Beautiful campus.
cons: Too much work for the small number of people in our department. My boss never goes home and is always super stressed and overwhelmed. It's hard to see any career path forward. Technology issues are very frustrating and troubleshooting them takes up too much valuable time.

review_title: Great place ... careful about the lab you join
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New York, NY
pros: Rockefeller is nice and has lots of benefits. Right by the hospital, university housing (a little noisy due to entrance to Manhattan and everyone honking all night long). There is a tennis court and 2 squash courts. Nice views!
cons: Your experience in with your adviser can be very different. When you get this high in academia, expect some un-compromising and non-understanding professors. I suggest interviewing the professor for personality before you accept.

review_title: Highly competitive, elite research institute that is something of a relic of bygone days.
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in New York, NY
pros: Lots of institutional money, great daycare/school for families, good health benefits, beautiful campus, top notch research, lots of flexibility and freedom in terms of the direction you take your work
cons: Gender inequity, no diversity, something of a company town, where University controls all aspects of your life (housing, healthcare, children’s school), mafia like in their management of professional conflict, pressure and pay people to keep quiet, no ombudsman/third party arbitration.

review_title: An amazing place with great science.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in New York, NY
pros: Great environment with many perks and benefits. Great helalthcare, very good housing, great salary compared to other institutions. Amazing scientific inputs with lots of seminars and always great lectures from invited guest.
cons: Depending on PI can be a very competitive environment with also poor mentorship. Postdoctoral duration in time usually extended here as high impact publications are a must have (can be a pros) . Not very collaborative place.

review_title: Excellent. One of the great American institutions
job_title: in New York, NY
pros: The environment, people and history are fantastic. Some of the smartest people on earth work at the university. They are open and accessible
cons: No real job growth. You start and end with the same job from the day you were hired. Some people don't mind this, but it can get old

job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Rockefeller has a wonderful work culture, especially great for recent college grads. The Research Assistant position is a great way to gain experience, and there are a lot of opportunities for learning outside the lab (lunch lectures, visiting scientists, etc) and also for socializing (there is a bar on campus, labs often have bbqs in the summer, and people are generally friendly).
cons: Your work experience can vary widely depending on your supervisor or the particular lab you are in

review_title: Ok. Not sure for long term advantages.
job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Good Benefits, Relaxed atmosphere.  A nice place to work in that the University is proud of their history and accomplishments.  Nice place to do research.  Child day care available.
cons: Not much room for growth.  Jobs are relatively unilateral.  To move up is difficult as the university likes to keep you in the same position.  Salary is also not very competitive.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Brooklyn, NY
pros: This golden opportunity I got from my high school. Our high school provide internship for their student on several sector, such as, Restaurant, Film Industry, Zoo, Park, Medical, and many technology based company. The working time was limited for interns. At that point I was also experiencing some financial problem.. That's why, I had to resign that work....
cons: The environment of animal research sector was so bad and smelly. Specially it was not good for us and other high school interns.

review_title: a secure job but no chance of advancement
job_title: IT Department in New York, NY
pros: I worled in the IT Dept for 10+ years. They are cutting edge in technology, no doubt. They have the financial resources to do so.
cons: No chance of advancement. 10 years after working here, I'm doing advanced, challenging work, but also still doing all the grunt work I was doing on day 1.

job_title: Care Technician in New York, NY
pros:
job security
Great gym
Nice library


Great medical benefits
Task oriented environment
cons:
Pay could be way better
No room for growth
No overtime
Not enough vacation days
Work culture needs to be diversified and reformed
Higher ups has allowed for hostile work environments to develop
Priority one workers do nothing but play on their cellphones all day everyday and have the least work assigned
Work politics

review_title: Avoid this place if you can
job_title: Animal Attendant in New York, NY
pros: Flexible scheduling and some wonderful co-workers
cons:
Favoritism, racism, sexism and everything that goes with the unholy Trinity of unprofessionalism. 

Management is extremely unprofessional.  There are inappropriate sexual relationships in management and it is not secretive. 

Many of the research technician do not care about the animals that they work with. 

IACUC is extremely weak and doesn't seem to care what goes on in the labs.

You get promoted base on how much gossip you bring to upper management and not on qualifications.

Absolutely no diversity in upper management.

job_title: Sales Associate in Abingdon, VA
pros: You feel comfortable in your work environment. They treat their staff like family. Always something to do.
cons: Hourly pay was not so great. Was a big change from what I was used to making.

review_title: Great place but stressful boss, never happy
job_title: Research Associate in New York, NY
pros: Great since and scientific environment. I enjoyed the talks from external and internal faculty/PIs.
cons: Only boss was never happy and not very encouraging though I co-authored over 12 research articles in high impact journals. The compensation  was very low, not increased for over 5 years.

review_title: Great place to start if you don't know what career to pursue after and undergraduate degree in the life sciences.
job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
-Great place to get lab experience if you are deciding between medical school or a Ph.D program
-Great benefits such as reimbursement for classes taken outside of the university and good health benefits
cons: The types of lab skills you will learn will vary depending on which lab you end up in.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Excellent subsidized health and dental benefits, generous vacation, on-site gym with classes, gorgeous atmosphere, and cutting edge science.
cons: For a place with Nobel-awarding winning scientists, some of the support staff (accounting, IT, some administrative assistants) are incompetent and don't care at all about their job.

review_title: Great place to work, very smart scientists, excellent learning environment
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Great people, very friendly. Beautiful campus environment. The work life balance is wonderful, because it's a university. The reputation is amazing, especially among the rest of the NY institutions.
cons: Pay was not up to par, especially to be located in NYC. The work in my particular department was repetitive. Not much transparency or room to move upwards.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in New York, NY
pros: Great minds (in-house and invited lecturers), vast resources, amazing housing opportunities, stimulating environment, outstanding job benefits, (small) but gorgeous campus.
cons: Small number of graduate students (no undergrad program) this only if you are looking for a larger-campus college experience. Independent drive is greatly encouraged, since most labs do not micro-manage students (I guess this is also a Pro).

job_title: Graduate Student in New York, NY
pros: Most labs have great funding and the resource centers are outstanding.  Grad students are taken care of so far as research resources are concerned.
cons: It's a crap shoot on whether you get a good thesis advisor.  Some PIs are more than happy to invest in their students' professional (and personal) success.  Others... not so much

job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in New York, NY
pros: Housing benefits in New York City Upper East Side and child daycare on t he site with great care and education. Furthermore there are many campus wide events that make it a great environment to work
cons: The nature of the job is very competitive and working in such environment makes the pressure for outstanding performance very high.

job_title: Associate Professor in New York, NY
pros: Research environment with no teaching responsibilities, excellent benefits, and availability of university-subsidized housing for academic staff. Excellent location on the lower Upper East Side of NYC.
cons: This is mostly a biomedical institution, organized as a collection of independent labs.  There are no departments: no philosophy, no literature, no mathematics, no history, etc., so exchange of ideas is limited.

review_title: Great Employer for the start or end of your career
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Coral Gables, FL
pros:
Great Work Life Balance
Extremely generous Retirement Plan
Great Employee Benefits offerings
cons:
The compensation is lower than for-profit employers
Hard to access by subway
There really isn't much else negative to say

job_title: Research Associate in New York, NY
pros: Great atmosphere, amazing scientists and good benefits. The university is home to the best people in bio-medical research
cons: Not enough collaboration, a formal approach would be required. Initiative should come from the laboratory heads, and also more organically.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New York, NY
pros: Rockefeller has a nice student and post doc community with warm and collegial environment with some great labs to get solid scientific experience, great housing with apartments overlooking the East river
cons: I can't think of any cons. It's located at one end of the city which may mean limited things to do around the area and limited transportation

job_title: Research Associate in New York, NY
pros: Facilities, Intelectual curiosity, Workethics, Opens many doors for future employment.
cons: Limited collaborations, each group its own entity, lots of Divas. Extremely high rents in Rockefeller residencies, that get back to them 65-70% of yr monthly salary.

review_title: They Take Care of Their Students
job_title: Graduate Fellow in New York, NY
pros: Fantastic environment for learning how to be a scientist.  The graduate program is very thoughtful and supportive of the needs of the students and is willing to work with their individual goals.  Wonderful access to leading researchers.  The housing is amazing.
cons: Really not much from a student's perspective.

job_title: Director in New York, NY
pros: Outstanding science to support.  Great on-site daycare, tennis court, free gym, free nutritionist, benefits are fabulous.  Feel like Rockefeller cares about me as a person.
cons: 15 walk from subway on top of commute. Need to hire more gym instructors to offer more free classes at better times.

review_title: Great research and a very nice campus
job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Great faculty and staff. Amazing opportunities to learn. Great campus with great location. Only the smartest people around. Intellectually stimulating. All labs are very well funded. Good food on campus. Free gym available. Good perks.
cons: Intellectually demanding. Demanding work schedule (depends on lab and position). Extremely high expectations of performance.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Child care is helpful for working families
cons: Limited opportunity outside of the lab for development. Heads of lab have the only say in faculty growth opportunities and its often misdirected.

job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Excellent benefits, better pay than the average academic institution.  Good starting point for any scientific career.
cons: A bit difficult to get to being four avenues from the nearest subway stop.  This salary combined with student loans (if you have them) makes finding affordable housing in range on the university a challenge.

review_title: I'm allowed to conduct interesting research, but opportunities for promotion or career advancement is very limited
job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in New York, NY
pros: Excellent support for your research, and opportunites to work at top labs in the world
cons: No opportunities for career advancement within a lab, very postdoc researcher has to leave the place to become independent lab heads or change careers

review_title: Probably one of the best places to work in academic biomedical research science.
job_title: Research Associate in New York, NY
pros: Good salary (for academia - obviously does not compare well to industry), great benefits / insurance plans etc., amazing housing provisions. World class core facilities and scientific environment. Tolerable level of bureaucracy.
cons: No complaints that are not common to academia at large.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: lots of flexibility in terms of research direction, good housing benefits. location is ok (UES), but easy access to most of NYC's more exciting areas
cons: work / life balance can be hard sometimes, long hours. compensation (stipend) good compared to other schools in the NYC area, but still on the low end

review_title: Academia at its highest, for better or worse
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New York, NY
pros: Amazing core facilities. Great benefits, especially for academia.
cons: Very privileged place that can be tone deaf at times. Heads of lab really run their own kingdoms and are not really subject to any real accountability so pick wisely.

job_title: Research Specialist in New York, NY
pros: It is a great culture for new grads trying to figure out if they want to go to graduate or medical school.
cons: There are not enough female Principal Investigators.

job_title: Assistant Teacher in New York, NY
pros: Great amount of vacation days compared to the small number other jobs give you. Many perks for working for the University. Your salary goes up every year. Beautiful campus & hidden gem in the city!
cons: No cons that I can think of.

review_title: Challenging place to do a PhD
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in New York, NY
pros:
Location is great and the campus is beautiful
Many opportunities to hear great scientific talks
Small graduate program
cons:
Not many serious courses offered, most are lecture series
PI mentorship and lab culture varies widely 
Students can get lost in post-doc heavy labs
Most students spend more than 5 years

review_title: Good place to start research career
job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Beautiful campus, friendly faculty, frequent seminars and guest speakers, some on and off-campus employee benefits and perks.
cons: Remote location and far from the train station, very little variety of lunch places,

job_title: Animal Attendant in New York, NY
pros: The university offers flexible scheduling and not much more.
cons: It is a typical work environment however, the management put a lot of unnecessary stress on the employees.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Great place, a lot for resources available, nice people and environment, active communication and collaboration, and many exciting projects going on.
cons:
Living expenses are high in New York City. 
compensation and salaries not really satisfactory
could have more career development guidance

review_title: Great place to learn new skills
job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
Rockefeller contributes to retirement after working 2 years.
Many on campus lectures to improve knowledge on various scientific techniques.
Decent health benefits from employee health.
Beautiful campus.
cons:
At times highly stressful to complete experiments in short time.
Not much room for advancement at Rockefeller.

job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
Access to the world's leading scientists and facilities via the neighboring institutions. 
Very challenging workplace and lots of responsibility early on.
cons:
PI and post-docs are very standoffish
Very little cohesion between the labs

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New York, NY
pros: Cutting edge science at the heart of NYC. Lot's of exposure to great Research.
cons: It's still academia and if you want to do something else with your life it's a high stress environment and still little money.

review_title: It's alright. It really depends what kind of graduate experience you want and who you work for.
job_title: Graduate Student in New York, NY
pros: Flexibility and relatively unstructured graduate environment
cons: It's really hard to live in NYC as a graduate student

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New York, NY
pros: Great people, great scientific minds, beautiful campus, great place to do science. The reputation is amazing amongst the people in life sciences area.
cons: Pay could be higher. Some core facilities needs a serious update of their old equipments.

review_title: Intellectually stimulating place for a tech
job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Good benefits, extreme opportunity to be exposed to high-end biology, if you're in a good lab you can really learn a lot and have good work/life balance
cons: Compensation is low, but average for technician positions

job_title: NICK CRAMER in Dalton, PA
pros: Best job I ever had from people, to atmosphere to benefits, the whole package. Have not come close to matching since
cons: The commute was my only issue with this job and the reason I left.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Great intellectual environment to be in
cons: It depends on who you work with.  Can be very pleasant or the opposite

review_title: Good quality of life, not always an exciting and challenging job
job_title: in New York, NY
pros: great hours, great health benefits, surrounded by very intelligent people
cons: paid time off accrual system; pettiness among senior staff; little to no room for career advancement

job_title: Veterinarian in New York, NY
pros: I had good co worker.
cons: no room for growth. the same folks working the same job for 30 years and more.

job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in New York, NY
pros:
working with very talented scientists and researchers 
affordable housing with subsidy and benefits
cons: it's a relatively small research-oriented institute, so there are not well-organized programs for career development for postdocs and students after RU

job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Good benefits, nice campus, relaxed working atmosphere.
cons: Salary is not competitive, promotions or raises are fairly difficult.  Positions are pretty unilateral.

job_title: Research Associate in New York, NY
pros:
great benefit including housing, daycare, medical/dental/vision insurances;
collaborative environment for research
cons: general living expense is high; almost no way to own a car which is not a problem mostly due to the public transportation NYC has

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New York, NY
pros: Very good structure and research environment. Great scientists and mentors, with several opportunities for collaborations and translational research.
cons: Hard balance work/social life, sometimes the university lacks a better way to connect with the postdocs.

job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Wonderful environment; free lectures and special events; beautiful campus; free beer on Wednesday nights at the Faculty Club; flexible work hours.
cons: Pay could be better but average for biomedical research; grant-based funding subject to cuts.

review_title: I've never worked with more sincere and caring people.
job_title: Project Manager in New York, NY
pros: Work environment like a large family; incredible work-life balance; frequent and constructive reviews; excellent advancement opportunities; annual cost-of-living salary increases
cons: Health insurance could be a bit better.

job_title: Freelance Start Up Operations in Astoria, NY
pros: Excellent benefits; supurb culture, relaxed environment, depending on the unit you are involved with.
cons: Pay is traditional academic rates and not competitive with the same positions in profit businesses; rare upward mobility for non-research staff

review_title: A very hierarchical org. and run scientists
job_title: Assistant Professor in New York, NY
pros: A very hierarchical org. and run by scientists.  A beautiful campus. Very cool science. Happy working here.
cons: Can seem a little disconnected from the rest of the world.

review_title: A great place to work at, with brilliant people but difficult to grow.
job_title: Assistant Professor of Clinical Investigation in New York, NY
pros:
Brilliant scientists
Incredible resources.
Great benefits, especially childcare.
cons:
Hierarchy
Isolation from medical centers (a problem for physicians).

job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Great campus. Good benefits. Serious research environment.
cons: Not much of a career path or salary growth. Seems expectations are that people will stay for 2 years and leave.

job_title: Graduate Student in New York, NY
pros: Great location, great resources, beautiful campus, great housing and student lifestyle is great.
cons: The big shots  rule , very few female professors, need to be a hustler to do ok.

job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in New York, NY
pros: Research environment is great! Faculties are approachable, which is an important part of a research organisation.
cons: This can be different at individual levels. My expectations were met here.

job_title: Graduate Research Fellow in New York, NY
pros: School funding for 5 years, interdisciplinary, access to the best resources
cons: Lack of departments can make it difficult to find other labs with shared interests

review_title: The Best Place I've Ever Worked
job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Exposure to the forefront of scientific research. Beautiful campus. Great community.
cons: This job propelled my scientific career - I can't think of any cons.

review_title: Very positive experience, not an academic environment like large grad schools
job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in New York, NY
pros: Wonderful resources and beautiful environment
cons: Missing enrichment activities found in institutions with many graduate students and very minimal collaborations.

review_title: Best school to study cancer & neurosciences
job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Small academy focused on cancer & neurosciences. Good benefits to employee. Best place for postdoctoral scientists.
cons: Not easy to make career change.

job_title: Postdoctoral Researcher in New York, NY
pros: Excellent research, great amenities, HR cares for the postdocs and makes their life as easy as possible
cons: Stressful city, demanding environment, work life balance can be tricky

review_title: Great academic environment with decent career development guidance
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in New York, NY
pros: Great science; good housing and daycare benefit; good salary in NYC.
cons: Mentorship is a hit or miss totally depending on your PI.

job_title: Research Specialist in New York, NY
pros:
Great people, friendly
They definitely treat their employees with respect
cons: The Pay is ok, but not great and there isn't really a career path for research staff.

job_title: Environmental Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Laid back, quality of life is valued.
cons: Some administrative staff are incompetent. Pay is not great at all.

job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in New York, NY
pros: Great resources in a collegial environment that has great minds.
cons: Living expenses are high. Housing is limited. But that is NYC for you.

job_title: Intern in New York, NY
pros:
- Friendly environment
- Simple projects
- Opportunity to interact with diverse types of people
cons:
- Difficult to advance in company (small group)
- Salary negotiations nonexistent

review_title: Rockefeller University is the THE place to be for researchers
job_title: Scientific Programmer in New York, NY
pros:
good benefit
good community activities
good HR and management team
cons: salary could be higher for research support staff

job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: unlimited access to seminars from some of the worlds greatest scientists
cons: tough commute if you dont live in manhattan

job_title: Senior Manager in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Good working environment, benefits, stability
cons: Limited flexibility to work from home, telecommute.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New York, NY
pros: lots of core facilities and resources to hasten research.
cons: not a super collaborative environment, overall, though individual labs may be collaborative.

job_title: Human Resources Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Excellent overall total compensation, stable industry, excellent work life balance.
cons: Career growth is stagnant and culture is very old-fashioned.

job_title: Senior Research Associate in New York, NY
pros: Rockefeller University is an excellent research place
cons: The PI was not good with Research staff

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Employees are recognized and appreciated
cons: While science is a priority ther are not much opportunities to grow in your proffecion

job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Important science being done with generally good-natured people
cons: Some members of senior management can be cold

review_title: A good place for research in New York
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New York, NY
pros: Good environment, competitive salary than other institute in NYC, good housing
cons: You have to work hard.

job_title: Senior Research Associate in New York, NY
pros: Provide housing, smart people, good healthcare, on site child care
cons: Recently they don’t allow children at faculty clib and holiday parties.

job_title: Research Associate Post Doc in New York, NY
pros: They help in professional development
cons: They are off the moment you mention that you want to work for the industry.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: A lot of talented scientists, access to a good but expensive healthcare plan
cons: Many benefits very limited compared to universities in other countries

review_title: Great place to start my career!
job_title: Development Officer in New York, NY
pros:
-supportive and fun team
-great first job out of college
cons:
-no transparency
-little to no room for growth or development

job_title: Research Associate in New York, NY
pros: Great place for early-level/training prior to transition to independence
cons: Competitive, not many options for long term employment and transition to independence.

job_title: Postdoctoral Researcher in New York, NY
pros: Amazing access to world class faculty and labs
cons: Salary is difficult to live on in NYC

job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in New York, NY
pros: Very nice environment, good health insurance, amazing opportunities for career growth.
cons: Not so many collaborations between laboratories.

job_title: Research Associate in New York, NY
pros: Infinite resources, genuine and passionate junior and support scientists who unfortunately are bullied by heads of labs
cons: Worst people to ever work for, each scientist is out for their own gain, no problem standing on top of bodies of graduate students and postdocs without giving them any credit for the work

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Oldenburg (Oldenburg)
pros: The science is amazing and the resources are plentiful.
cons: Like most other scientific institutions, it lacks in diversity.

job_title: Finance in Cologne
pros:
Family friendly environment
Campus parking
Campus child care
Unlimited sick leave

job_title: Assistant Manager in Salzburg
pros: The Best place to work in New York.
cons: Anything wrong to say about RU. But the best.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Stuttgart
pros: Housing, Health Insurance, Day Care

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New York, NY
pros: Nice atmosphere, nice people, very good human resources

review_title: It is a great place to work
job_title: Research Associate in New York, NY
pros: The best place for scientist

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Good working environment, can keep work life balance.

job_title: Research Associate in New York, NY

review_title: Great place to be a graduate student

job_title: in New York, NY

job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
